title-group.article-title: Pesticide Exposure and Endocrine Dysfunction in the Cotton Crop Agricultural Workers of Southern Punjab, Pakistan

article-meta.aff: 1National University of Science and Technology, Rawalpindi, Pakistan

author-notes.corresp: Dilshad A. Khan, Department of Pathology, Army Medical College, National University of Science and Technology, Rawalpindi 49000, Pakistan. Email: dilshad@nust.edu.pk

permissions.copyright-holder: Asia-Pacific Academic Consortium for Public Health

abstract.p: This study evaluated pesticide effects on reproductive and thyroid hormones of cotton farmers of southern Punjab, Pakistan. A total of 88 cotton farmers (42 spray applicators and 46 cotton pickers) were randomly included with an equal number of age- and sex-matched controls. Sampling was done in high spraying and peak picking seasons. Serum levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), testosterone, prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), total triiodothyroxine (TT3), and free thyroxine (fT4) were carried out by enzymatic immunoassay. Plasma cholinesterase (PChE) levels were measured by Ellman’s method. Serum FSH, LH, and testosterone levels were significantly high in spray applicators (P < .01).Serum FSH and testosterone levels were significantly raised in cotton pickers (P < .01). Serum prolactin was decreased significantly in both groups (P < .01).Serum fT4 was significantly reduced in cotton pickers (P < .01). Pesticide exposure is associated with thyroid and reproductive hormone levels disturbance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pesticides are used extensively in the agricultural sector to control insects and pests that commonly attack and destroy the crops. World-wide deaths and chronic diseases due to pesticide poisoning number about 1 million per year.1 Studies have shown that these chemicals pose a potential risk to the human health and contaminate the environment at the same time.2

Cotton is the most important cash crop of Pakistan with about 80% of foreign exchange being earned through cotton exports.3 It is also the crop most heavily attacked by pests leading to about 80% of the total pesticides in Pakistan being consumed on the cotton crop.4 According to the Sustainable Development Policy Institute (SDPI) report, women are at high risk of pesticide exposure in cotton fields because more than 90% work of cotton picking is done by women agricultural workers.5 The Technical Bulletin (2000) states that the use of pesticide in Pakistan has increased by 1169% in the past 20 years and the number of sprays per crop has reached more than 10, which is an alarming situation for human health.6

A few human studies were carried out to see the effect of pesticides on the thyroid hormones in agricultural workers, but there is great discrepancy between the results obtained.7,8 A reasonable number of studies were carried out in Pakistan to study the adverse effects of pesticides on human health.9,10 However, by far very few studies have been carried out to observe the endocrine disrupting effects of these chemicals on the reproductive and thyroid hormones in the Pakistani agricultural workers. This observation points toward the need of identifying the adverse effects of these pesticides on the endocrine system of the cotton farmers in our country for monitoring and creating awareness among masses about the proper use of pesticides.

sec.title: Study Area
sec.p: Cotton is grown on more than 3 million hectares in Pakistan, which constitutes 15% of the total cultivated area. A total of 16 districts, mainly in southern Punjab, account for about 80% of national cotton growing area, with most of the remainder being cultivated in Sindh.

The province of Punjab in Pakistan has a network of canals leading out from the river Indus, which drain the area. The case–control study was carried out in Multan, Vehari, Kabirwala, and Bahawalpur districts, which constitute the cotton belt of the Punjab, Pakistan, in collaboration with National Agriculture Research Centre (NARC), Islamabad. Biochemical analyses were conducted at the Clinical Pathology Laboratory (CPL), Army Medical College (AM College), Rawalpindi after approval from the Institutional Review Committee of AM College, Rawalpindi. The duration of the study was 1 year, from April 2009 to May 2010.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: A total of 120 agricultural workers were randomly chosen from the Municipal Committee records containing information regarding the exact activities performed and timing of exposure to pesticides. Out of these 88 farmers, 42 spray applicators and 46 cotton pickers aged between 18 and 65 years were recruited after informed consent. Subjects were residents of the area for more than a year and were involved in full-time spraying and cotton picking. Those suffering from any endocrine disorder or any acute or chronic illness were excluded. Equal number of age- and sex-matched controls residing >60 km from the pesticide spraying area who were not suffering from any acute or chronic disease were included.

sec.title: Clinical History and Medical Examination
sec.p: A structured questionnaire based on the questionnaire issued by the NARC (Pakistan) was completed by the agricultural workers. General physical examination was carried out by a qualified doctor. Environmental analysis was also done.

sec.title: Sample Collection
sec.p: Blood samples were collected in 2 phases during the high spraying (July-September, 2009) and the peak picking seasons (October-December, 2009). Ten milliliters of blood sample was taken from the applicators (between 7:00 and 10:00 am) by trained personnel using nonheparinized vacutainer tubes 1 day after pesticides were applied at the workplace. Samples from cotton pickers were taken toward the end of the peak cotton picking season. Ten milliliters of blood sample was taken from the controls. Samples were centrifuged for 10 minutes at 2500 rpm and serum was stored at −70°C till analysis.

sec.title: Soil Samples
sec.p: Randomized composite soil sampling was done. A total of 23 composite field soil samples (n = 10) from a depth of 1 to 6 inches were collected in plastic bags with the help of corer. All the stones, pebbles, and organic matter were removed from the sample collected (≥1 kg). The whole collected soil sample was dried, well mixed, and sieved. The QuEChER (quick, easy, chief, effective, and robust) extraction method was adopted. The lab sample (500 g) was ground to powder in pestle and mortar and passed through a 200 mesh size sieve. Exactly 5 g of analytical portion was taken out in test tubes in duplicate and vortexed with 10 mL distilled water and 10 mL acetonitrile. Then 4 g of anhydrous magnesium sulfate and 1.66 g of sodium acetate trihydrate were added and immediately vortexed to avoid formation of magnesium conglomerates. The tubes were centrifuged at 3500 rpm for 5 minutes. From these tubes 8 mL aliquots were taken out in another test tube. To this aliquot, 10 mL distilled water and 30 mL n-hexane were added and vortexed again. Twenty-five milliliters were taken out of the upper n-hexane layer and put into a round-bottom flask, evaporated to dryness on a rotavapor, and reconstituted in 1 mL n-hexane for gas chromatographic analysis.

sec.title: Water Samples
sec.p: A total of 22 human drinking water samples were collected. Groundwater samples were collected from hand pumps of about 40 to 50 feet in depth from the abovementioned location. The water samples were collected in prewashed bottles and fortified with dichloromethane to stop biological activities. Liquid–liquid extraction procedure was adopted for extraction of pesticides from water samples. One liter of water sample was taken out in a separating funnel and the pesticides were extracted with 75 mL of dichloromethane. The separating funnel was kept in a stand till 2 distinct phases were formed. The lower oily layer was collected in a round-bottom flask over a small cotton wool plug and anhydrous Na2SO4. A few drops of propylene glycol in ethylacetate (1:1) solution and about 3 to 4 glass beads were added. The contents were evaporated on a rotavapor at 40°C under vacuum and optimum rotation speed. For complete dryness, nitrogen stream was used. The contents were reconstituted in 1 mL n-hexane for gas chromatographic analysis.

The pesticide standards were purchased from Riedel-de Haën AG (Seelze, Germany). Their stock solutions and required working dilutions were prepared in n-hexane and acetone. The solvents and reagents used in this study were from Merck, BDH, and Reidel-de-Haën and were of extra pure gas chromatography or high-performance liquid chromatography grade.

sec.title: Plasma Cholinesterase Analysis
sec.p: Blood samples were also collected in heparanized tubes. The plasma was separated by centrifugation at 1000 × g for 10 minutes. Plasma cholinesterase (PChE) levels were estimated by Ellman’s method11 using GD Italy kits on Vita Lab Selectra E (Netherlands). The coefficient of variance of the method was found to be 3%.

sec.title: Hormonal Analysis
sec.p: Serum levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), testosterone, prolactin, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), total triiodothyroxine (TT3), and free thyroxine (fT4) were estimated by enzymatic immunoassay on Access II Hormone Analyzer (Beckman Coulter Reagent Pack, Brea, CA). Intra-assay coefficient of variance of the method was <5.0% for each of the analytes.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS software version 17 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, IL). Kolmogorov–Smirnov test was applied on the data, which revealed non-Gaussian distribution for all the variables (P < .05). Descriptive statistics were done. Mann–Whitney U test was applied among the 2 main groups of farmers and their respective control groups. Spearman correlation analysis was applied between plasma acetylcholinestrase levels and reproductive and thyroid hormone profile parameters in cotton pickers and spray applicators. A P value of .05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The spray applicators were males of mean age 37 years (SD = 14.9) whereas the cotton pickers were females of mean age 39 years (SD = 14.5). The demographic characteristics are given in Table 1.

caption.p: Demographic Characteristics of Cases and Controls.

sec.title: Assessment of Exposure
sec.p: A quantitative evaluation of exposure was done, and the results are given in Table 2. PChE concentration was significantly declined in both groups as compared with controls (P < .01).

caption.p: Quantitative Exposure Assessment and Distribution of Symptoms Reported by the Cotton Crop Agricultural Workers.

tr.td: No. of times sprayed/cotton picked per season (mean ± SD)

sec.p: Soil and water samples contained varying levels of pesticide residues (Table 3), most abundant being fenpropathrin. Similar samples obtained from the residential area of controls contained negligible pesticide residues.

caption.p: Descriptive Statistics of Pesticide Residues (mg/kg) Detected in Environmental Samples (Soil/Water) From the Affected Area (Pesticide-Wise Contamination).

fn.p: Abbreviations: OP, organophosphate pesticides; OC = organochlorine pesticides; Py = pyrethroids; α-BHC, alpha benzene hexachloride; γ-BHC, gamma benzene hexachloride; DDT, dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane; DDE, dichlorodiphenyldichloroethylene.

sec.title: Health Hazards
sec.p: Muscular weakness, skin burns, breathing difficulty, coughing, nausea, and vomiting were more common among spray applicators whereas headache and muscular weakness were quite high among cotton pickers (Table 2). Majority of farmers did not use any protective equipment. Findings are shown in Figure 1.

caption.p: Protective measures taken by spray applicators (n = 42) and cotton pickers (n = 46) while working as a tool for assessment of exposure to pesticides.

sec.title: Hormonal Analyses
sec.p: Reproductive hormones were significantly high in agricultural workers as compared with controls (P < .05; Tables 4 and 5). No significant rise in serum LH was observed in the cotton pickers (Table 5). Serum prolactin was significantly decreased in both groups (P < .01; Tables 4 and 5). Thyroid hormones did not vary significantly between spray applicators and the control group (Table 4). Serum fT4 was significantly reduced in cotton pickers as compared with the controls (P < .01; Table 5).

caption.p: Comparison of Endocrine Parameters of Spray Applicators (n = 42) and the Control Group (n = 42).

fn.p: Abbreviations: FSH, follicle-stimulating hormone; LH, luteinizing hormone; TSH, thyroid-stimulating hormone; TT3, total triiodothyronine; fT4, free thyroxine; PChE, plasma cholinesterase.

caption.p: Comparison of Endocrine Parameters of Cotton Pickers (n = 46) and the Control Group (n = 45).

fn.p: Abbreviations: FSH, follicle-stimulating hormone; LH, luteinizing hormone; TSH, thyroid-stimulating hormone; TT3, total triiodothyronine; fT4, free thyroxine; PChE, plasma cholinesterase.

sec.title: Correlation Analysis
sec.p: On applying Spearman correlation analysis, significant negative correlation was observed between PChE levels, serum FSH, LH, testosterone, and prolactin levels in the spray applicators. Significant negative association was observed between PChE, serum FSH, and prolactin levels in the cotton pickers whereas positive association was observed with serum fT4 as shown in Table 6.

caption.p: Spearman Correlation Between Plasma Cholinesterase, Reproductive and Thyroid Hormone Profile in Spray Applicators and Cotton Pickers.

fn.p: Abbreviations: FSH, follicle-stimulating hormone; LH, luteinizing hormone; TSH, thyroid-stimulating hormone; TT3, total triiodothyronine; fT4, free thyroxine.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The reproductive hormone profile of our spray applicators demonstrated a significant rise in FSH, LH, and testosterone. A study reported that pyrethroid metabolites in spot urine samples were positively associated with FSH and LH.12 Another study suggested that organophosphate exposure disrupts hypothalamic–pituitary endocrine axis whereby average serum FSH levels are higher during the heavy pesticide spraying season.13 Padungtod et al14 reported that organophosphate exposure significantly increased serum LH and FSH levels whereas those of testosterone were decreased. In contrast, certain studies have not reported any significant association between pesticide exposure and serum levels of reproductive hormones.15

In case of spray applicators, there was exposure to a large dose of pesticides in a relatively short duration of time. A study reported that subchronic administration of quinalphos increased serum levels of LH, FSH, and testosterone.16 A probable explanation may be that pesticides act as gonadotrophin-releasing hormones (GnRH) analogues enhancing release of FSH and LH.17 High LH concentrations stimulate Leydig cells to release large amounts of testosterone with loss of feedback mechanism.16 Another probability could be that the pesticides may have decreased the concentration of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) leading to increased serum concentration of testosterone.

The cotton pickers in our study showed significant increase in FSH and testosterone with no significant effect on LH. The findings of our study are consistent with those of Ahmad et al,18 who observed minor changes in LH in female workers. Rizwan et al19 monitored higher values of LH and FSH in blood samples of female cotton workers. The average number of exposure years and the average hours spent in cotton picking were higher than those of the spray applicators. A possible explanation of the findings in our study may be that pesticides act through hormone agonist action at receptors20 on the ovaries enhancing release of testosterone in case of female cotton pickers. Rise in FSH may be attributed to decreased synthesis of inhibin, which results in alteration in the negative feedback mechanism. LH also shows an increasing trend; however, in case of the cotton pickers this change was not significant. This is in accordance with the observation that toxicant-induced endocrine alterations may differ in outcome in male and female.21

Serum prolactin was decreased significantly in both groups. This is in agreement with a study carried out on flower growers whereby it was seen that pesticide exposure decreases serum prolactin levels.22 However, our finding is in contrast to Sarkar et al,16 who observed an increase in serum prolactin levels after administration of quinalphos. Another study found no significant association between organophosphates and serum prolactin levels.23 A probable explanation for our observation is that prolactin and estrogen have reciprocal endocrinologic relationship. Estrogen stimulates prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary by inhibition of dopaminergic suppression.24 Most of the pesticides used may have anti-estrogenic actions25 leading to diminished production of prolactin. Pesticides can also alter the levels of neurotransmitters and inhibit the activity of acetylcholinesterase, monoamine oxidase-A, and monoamine oxidase-B, which causes a reduction in the serum levels of prolactin.22

As far as the thyroid profile is concerned, there was no significant change in the hormones in case of the spray applicators. However, fT4 showed a marginal decrease and TSH demonstrated slight trend toward increase. This is in partial agreement with a study carried out on pesticide formulators which indicated significant suppression of total T3 whereas marginal decrease was noticed in T4 levels, and TSH values were only slightly elevated.26 Similarly, concerning fT4 and TT3, several authors observed either no associations or negative associations between organochlorines and these hormones.27-29 In contrast, Toft et al8 found higher TSH level, a lower TT3, free triiodthyroxine (FT3), and fT4 in low spraying season as compared with high spraying seasons.8

Our cotton pickers showed a significant decrease in the fT4 levels. Several pesticides have been associated with decrease in fT4 level.30,31 This could probably be because of conversion of fT4 to reverse T3 (rT3) as a result of chronic pesticide exposure leading to “sick euthyroid syndrome.” Findings of a study suggest that organophosphate compounds may result in “sick euthyroid syndrome.”32 Another possibility could be the increased hepatic metabolism of fT4 with activation of the enzymes involved in thyroid hormone metabolism such as 5′-deiodinase type II (D2). This leads to increased synthesis of T3 from T4.7

As far as the health implications are concerned, muscular weakness and headache were the most commonly reported symptoms. Muscular weakness is mainly due to the actions of organophosphate at the muscarinic receptor sites.33 Organophosphates bind acetylcholinesterase resulting in acetylcholine excess at the muscarinic receptor sites, eventually causing muscular weakness. Breathing difficulty and skin burns were more often reported by the spray applicators. This was mainly because of direct exposure to the spray contents via inhalation and through dermal contact as a result of lack of use of any protective instrument such as mask or gloves.34 A survey carried out among sugarcane farmers in Fiji found significant differences in the incidence of chronic illness and disease between users of pesticides and a nonuser control group.35 Public health authorities can learn from this debate regarding need for use of specific rather than general health warnings and proper training regarding pesticide usage.36

The strengths of our study are that it is the first study of its kind to be conducted in Pakistan that has simultaneously evaluated the endocrine effects of pesticides in both the spray applicators and cotton pickers forming a basis of comparison between the 2 groups for future researchers. It will also help in unraveling the exact mechanism of endocrine disruption observed in our agricultural workers. Instead of relying purely on the history given by the agricultural workers, PChE levels were measured and environmental analysis was done to assess the extent of exposure. PChE levels are more reliable than the symptoms for risk assessment and monitoring of pesticides intoxication in the farm workers.37 Furthermore, we used other methods to evaluate exposure, such as the average number of exposure years and average number of hours spent actively in spraying or cotton picking for better quantitative assessment.8,38 We also identified pesticide residues in soil and groundwater samples. Pesticides can enter groundwater resources during rainfall, hence contributing to the risk of environmental contamination.

A potential limitation of the study could be that a longitudinal analysis would have been better to see the effect on the hormones in the same group of farmers during the high spraying and low spraying seasons. Moreover, assessment of pesticide metabolite levels in urine of the farmers may have been a better indicator of exposure. Finally, since the farmers were exposed to a number of pesticides we were unable to pinpoint the exact chemicals that are the culprits for the observed effects.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Pesticide exposure significantly elevated serum FSH and serum testosterone and decreased serum prolactin levels in the cotton farmers. Thyroid hormones remained unaffected in spray applicators whereas serum fT4 was mainly reduced in the cotton pickers. Pesticide exposure is associated with disturbance in the thyroid and reproductive hormone levels in agricultural workers.
